citation.article-title: Pimelobacter gen. nov., a new genus of coryneform bacteria with LL-diaminopimelic acid in the cell wall.
citation.source: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pimelobacter jensenii sp. nov.
Pimelobacter jensenii (jen. se'ni. i. M. L. gen, n. jensenii of Jensen; named for H. L. Jensen, the Danish bacteriologist who contributed to the taxonomy of coryneform bacteria)
Irregular rods, 0.6 to 0.8 by 3.0 to 7.0 μm are formed in one-day culture and 0.6 to 1.0 by 0.8 to 1.0 μm in seven-day culture on YM agar.
Branching is not distinctive.
Small coccoid forms are found dominantly in old culture.
Aerial mycelia are not formed.
Non-motile.
Gram positive.
Colonies are glossy, smooth, entire, and slightly yellowish white on YM agar.
DNase activity is weak.
Urease is positive.
Acid is not produced from sugars.
Glucose, sucrose, and L-rhamnose are assimilated.
Acetate is assimilated, but succinate is not.
No nutritional requirement.
Aerobic.
The DNA base composition is 68.8 % G+C.
LL-Diaminopimelic acid and glycine are the principal amino acids in the cell wall.
Cellular fatty acid composition is the complex type.
Small amounts of 2-hydroxy fatty acids are found.
The type strain is P. jensenii CNF 091 (=NCIB 9770, =IAM 12581, =JCM 1364).
